awd_titl_txt: Reinvigorating Information Technology Education with Cybersecurity

perf_inst.perf_inst_name: University of New Mexico Los Alamos Branch

por.por_cntn:
Our project created a quality associate degree in Information Technology with Cyber Security as a focus.  We designed a program that includes critical thinking, problem-solving, and ethical issues, as well as the usual skills sets in associate level IT work. It has been industry reviewed by IT experts at our national laboratory in Los Alamos and IT professionals at Los Alamos County. 

Continued mapping of the curriculum to CISSPcertification  standards is ongoing. Additional concentrations to increase expertise are under consideration.

Our plan to create a pipeline means that we have created awareness of and participation in IT from youth, middle school and high school with summer programs, "Capture the Flag" and other "challenge" events, and even females only events. 

We provided high school teacher training for IT and created a high school level IT curriculum mapped to common core standards, which is available for any high school that requests it. 

Our two-year degree also offers the opportunity for students to compete for an internship at Los Alamos National Lab.  Such an internship provides ten weeks of training in various departments, so students gain real workplace knowledge, soft skills needed by employers, and - in our case - job offers at the end of the internship. 

Additional student support was built  by increasing our Academic Support Center's capacity, as well as working with Student Services advisors and faculty, with intrusive advising and tutoring, particularly in math.  Progress toward degree is a primary concern when over 90% of our students work and support families, so education is an additional but incredible important aspect of their lives.

Advanced IT training offered through continuing education, with Attack Research providing "Red Hat" type workshops furthered the idea of a pipeline of IT education even to career IT specialists.  An 18-hour  CISSP certification review course was also offered to our community and professionals.

Community awareness and participation in IT was created through home computer security classes. Partnerships  with Los Alamos National Lab and Los Alamos County included curricuum review and recruitment of adjunct faculty. We have some of the most qualified IT faculty in the nation. 

Our achievements came in spite of significant challenges, including a delay in processing and inputting our new degree into the University of New Mexico's system, which took over 12 months longer than expected.  This delayed everything.  The difficulty and in fact, resulting failure to find full time faculty was another challenge.  A small two-year college cannot compete with national lab salaries, and in these days of budget cuts, no additional funds were available to compete.  We do have, however, partnering with the lab to find great adjuncts who serve our students well.

Our partnering work with SUN Online, a New Mexico attempt like Maryland online, with course sharing, etc is uncertain at this point, since that program does not appear to be sustainable now that its grant funds are gone  That was a loss, but our offerings include many online options, so flexibility for our students does exist.

An upgraded, ADA accessible IT classroom provides students with the opportunity to work on a separate network to do challenges, attacks, pen testing,etc. 

We consider the links to our high school teachers and possible programs to be a key element that we'd just begun to address this year.  We hope that the curriculum we have designed for high schools that meets common core standards is a significant step forward.  However, New Mexico schools often have few qualified teachers in IT.
